Topic.Title: Cramer: screens all questions prior to answering

Message.Msg: Cramer listened to my question on TV in October. That telephonic question was recorded in September, and that phone call was one month after I had sent an e-mail asking the question and his people thought it was good enough to ask the question on TV. A two-month delay! The start and end of his show may be current, but other parts of his show are taped delayed. His specific comments about individual companies may be questionable but his portfolio management discussions are pretty much on the mark. Does anyone really think that he can be prepared, on a moment's notice (when people ask about a company), to answer questions about any of 30,000 publicly-held companies? And that's with a considerable staff behind him.

Topic.Title: Apple Dumping Intel In The MacBook? Don't Believe This Bogus Rumor

Message.Msg: Designing a chip is one thing. Making it is another. There are about two dozen layers of fine micro-circuitry on an INTC chip, and it takes more than 500 individual steps (and more than a month) to make it. And you need lots of expensive equipment to do it. That's why fab plants are $8 billion each. You have to pay to play. When you have someone else make your chip for you, you lose control over the product (quality, quantity). Just ask Apple.

Topic.Title: NVDA earnings up by 17% on strong demand for ARM based Tegra chirp

Message.Msg: Nvidia's profit still comes from its gpus which are still totally reliant on high performance Intel cpus to sell so be careful what you wish for ;-). With a bit of luck the Tegra division, CPB, might have come close to breakeven this quarter but that is not certain until the 10-Q comes out.

Topic.Title: NVDA earnings up by 17% on strong demand for ARM based Tegra chirp

Message.Msg: MSFT and INTC may have been late to the party but they are both turning up with good competitive products now, Windows 8, Medfield, Clovertrail and soon Clovertrail+. Tegra revenue is probably about the same as Atom revenue now so that is not the best example of the FUD you are trying to portray ;-). PC revenue will pick up again in 2013 anyway when Windows 8 and especially Haswell strut their stuff so all the gloom and doom merchants will have to find a new bashing angle ;-).

Message.Title: Will Intel drastically reduce the dividend or never increase it again?
Message.Msg: According to the report, the Senate Democrats’ plan to shift the tax burden onto upper-income wage earners will likely cause them to shift their investments—here and abroad—to those that are taxed at lower rates. This in turn will likely cause dividend-paying companies to reduce the size of their quarterly dividend checks.

Message.Title: A world of Cramerian balderdash
Message.Msg: Cramerian balderdash: That's all I have read on the "Intel News" list for the past week. It's repetitive spew by people who simply don't know anything. This is how "investment advice" is disseminated nowadays. I have never seen such a clear example of disinformation, short of the Republican attack ads, that lost for them the last election. If you believe a fabless company like Qcom is really better than a giant megolith like Intel, than I urge you to bet your farm on qcom. But don't give me the balderdash that the fact Intel is design, development AND fab somehow makes it weak. And of course, Cramerian balderdash doesn't witness the 28nm shortage and what really underlies it all. AND, to backbay, et al, who charge that Ottelini should go because he isn't counter-spewing....let me say that if I witnessed Ottelini counter-spewing balderdash, I would see it as a weakness..a cover-up. Silence, while carrying a very large stick, is the best policy.

Topic.Title: From Barrons

Message.Msg: If INTC were buying back options at this low price, I'd be all for it. However, if they are issueing stock options for their miserable stock performance, they should be looking for a class action law suit.

Topic.Title: From Barrons

Message.Msg: It would be very hard to file a class action lawsuit for issuing stock options to employees since a very large majority of us (the shareholders) approved it at the annual meeting. The issuing of stock options is just part of employee compensation for every modern company. Stock options are issued and are designed to lock high value employees into the company by their staggered vesting and incremental awarding of shares. Option stock that is finding its way into the market today was awarded between 1 and 5 years ago. There is no metric inside a company that is explicitly awarded based on the performance of the company stock. None that I can think of.

Topic.Title: I told you so

Message.Title: Just A Thought
Message.Msg: Nothing is worse than fear than fear itself. Unlike earnings and revenues, the fiscal cliff doesn't offer investors a number to work, just a gloomy picture. There was some talk about the potential effect on the GDP should the U. S. go over the cliff at the end of the year. But there is no clear picture in terms of how much consumers might tighten their pocket book when the tax cuts expire or how much corporations may change their businesses over Obamacare. The market seemed to be dominated more by fear than actual economic expectation. In addition, those who had expected Romney to win might have been so disappointed that they capitulated. Technically, all three major indexes are now below their respective 200-day moving averages suggesting the downtrend started in September could morph into a longer term downtrend. Don't try to catch a falling knife. Wait for the market to find some stabilization before step in. For the S&P 500, watch for support near 1370, a 50% retracement of the gain from June low to September high. have a nice day

Topic.Title: Just A Thought

Message.Msg: "Nothing is worse than fear than fear itself." I think that those who spread fear for personal gain are worse. Not referring to you. The "fiscal cliff" is more of a "fiscal beach". There are triggers but the effects are much more sloping in their impact. Expect that the lame duck congress will not do anything before Jan. We have just started the brinksmanship game and the game cannot finish until the brink is upon us. The Democrats will allow the tax cuts to expire if they are pushed. With 70% of the electorate supporting another tax bracket and the CBO saying it has minor effect, the Republicans will get the credit for the expiration. (Reuters) - Allowing income tax rates to rise for wealthy Americans, and maintaining rates for the less affluent, would not hurt U.S. economic growth much in 2013, the Congressional Budget Office said on Thursday, stepping into a dispute between Republicans and Democrats over how to resolve the so-called "fiscal cliff."

Message.Title: Austek sees October revnue increase
Message.Msg: Asustek Computer on November 8 reported non-consolidated revenues of NT$35.555 billion (US$1.213 billion) for October, growing 5.31% on month and 13.60% on year. Revenues for January-October were NT$305.002 billion, rising 15.86% on year. The sequential growth in October revenues was mainly due to larger than expected shipments of the Nexus 7, and notebooks, especially shipments to North America and Europe , Asustek indicated.

Topic.Title: Austek sees October revnue increase

Message.Msg: The last half of the Digitimes article: Asustek has obtained higher than expected orders for VivoBook series Windows 8 touch-control notebooks, with more than 600,000 units to be shipped by the end of 2012, the company noted. Therefore, the goal of 20% of notebook shipments being Windows 8 touch models can be reached, Asustek said. Asustek expects its non-consolidated revenues for November to increase on month to the highest monthly level in the fourth quarter thanks to touch-controlled notebooks, the company indicated. NOTE that ... THE VIVOBOOK series Windows 8 touch notebooks are $599 version of Win8 Intel Core i3 system.

Message.Title: INTC will give APPL nightmares
Message.Msg: All this rumor about how APPL will hurt INTC if it switches to its to ARM chip for macs...nonsense. Has anyone considered the opposite? That INTC will will give APPL nightmares in the near future due to their upcoming chips? - INTC is coming out with a powerful z2580 chip for smartphones and small tablets. Will have dual core and have hyperthreading. These will be more powerful than the current ARM chips (including the A15), have integrated LTE 4G and require less power. INTC will win multiple android phone and tablets designs with this chip. Phones using this chip will rival that of the Samsung s3 but more powerful - giving AAPL further fits. Remember INTC has agreement with Google to support android and a multi year agreement with motorola also. - INTC is coming out with haswell chip for PC/convertible market in early 2013. These are slightly more powerful than current Ivy Bridge but require way less power. It also has very powerful integrated graphics. Will be built on 22nm technology. The touch capabilities of windows 8 will make hybrid or convertible PCs very popular in the future. Why buy 2 devices when you can just buy one and have it all? On top of that the new devices will be thin...very thin ...rivalling thinnest of the macbook air! Imagine that? A convertible PC as thin as macbook air! Very sexy!

Topic.Title: From Barrons

Message.Msg: Intel has only about six smartphones to its credit so far – XOLO X900 by Lava International, Lenovo LePhone 800, Android smartphone code-named San Diego, LTE Grand X IN, Megafon Mint and the recently launched Motorola Razor I. Additionally, Intel claims to have around 20 tablet design in its pipeline up for launch this year. On the other hand, ARM technology powers some of the most popular devices and is present in a number of smartphone and tablet devices in the market. Some of the products enabled by ARM’s technology are – Apple’s iPhone and iPad, Amazon Kindle2, Samsung Galaxy Tab, Samsung Galaxy S, HTC Sensation, HTC Desire, Samsung Omnia, Asus PDA and Acer beTouch400 among many others.

Message.Title: Qualcomm overtakes Intel in market capitalization
Message.Msg: Guess it's more than all about who has got the best fabs... Qualcomm uses ARM CPUs... ------------------------------------------------------------------------ LONDON – Qualcomm's standing as the leading supplier of application processors for mobile devices – and the fact that it is fabless – has boosted its market capitalization past Intel Corp., the world's largest chip maker. San Diego-based Qualcomm is expected to increase its sales by 30 percent in 2012, according to market researcher IC Insights. Qualcomm's annual chips sales are expected to reach about $12.8 billion in annual chip sales, moving it three spots in the researchers' rankings to No. 4. Although Intel (Santa Clara, Calif.) remains the No. 1 chip maker as measured by sales volume, its standing relies on its dominant position in PCs, a market that is now perceived to be flat at best as consumers embrace smartphones and tablet computers. Those mobile devices are often powered by Qualcomm's Snapdragon processors. In the eyes of investors who have driven up its market capitalization, the fact that Qualcomm is a fabless company relieves it of the burden of having to invest billions of dollars each year in process development and wafer fabs. As a result, Qualcomm's share price stands at $61.83, giving it a current market capitalization of $105 billion. Intel's market capitalization stands at $104 billion based on a share price of $20.96. According to IC Insights, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.'s market cap is about $84 billion, followed by Texas Instruments at about $33 billion. Micron Technologies is valued at $5.75 billion and STMicroelectronics at $4.9 billion. ST's value is about half that of processor IP licensor ARM Holdings

Message.Title: Cray Ditches AMD for Supercomputers, chooses Intel
Message.Msg: Cray Opts for Intel Chips for Newest Supercomputers By Jeffrey Burt | Posted 2012-11-09 Email this article Email Print this article Print Cray’s XC30, the first of the company’s next-generation supercomputers, will run on Intel’s Xeon chips, and eventually include Intel’s Xeon Phi coprocessors. Cray, which has used Opteron processors from Advanced Micro Devices for most of their supercomputers, is now embracing Intel chips for its new XC30 supercomputer line. The XC30—which had been codenamed Cascade—is Cray’s next-generation supercomputer product line, and the first of the XC portfolio, which will replace the current XE and XK brands as the company’s flashship HPC family, according to Barry Bolding, Cray’s vice president of corporate marketing. The new systems not only will come with Intel’s Xeon chips, but they also will feature significant improvements in interconnect technology and bandwidth, performance, energy efficiency and high-performance computing (HPC) software support. Bolding noted that the current AMD-based XE Blue Waters and XK Titan systems have been stalwarts in Cray’s supercomputer lineup as it has competed with the likes of IBM, Fujistu, Hewlett-Packard and others. “We anticipate that XC will be just as important to our competitiveness going forward,” he told eWEEK. The HPC server space is becoming increasingly competitive, not only with the continued demand from scientific and educational institutions, but also the growth in large enterprise data centers that need the same performance, scalability and energy efficiency capabilities. According to market research firm IDC, revenue in the HPC technical server space in the second quarter hit $2.4 billion. In 2011, overall revenues hit $10.3 billion, and analysts expect to see that number jump to $11 billion this year. IBM had 32.7 percent of the market in the quarter, followed by HP, with 29.8 percent, and Dell, with 14.2 percent. Cray during the quarter saw its revenues jump 43.7 percent, according to IDC. Cray’s announcement comes less than a week before the SC12 supercomputing show opens Nov. 12 in Salt Lake City, Utah. Cray’s XC30 system—which will be able to scale to more than 100 petaflops of performance—initially will be powered by Intel’s current 32-nanometer Xeon E5-2600 “Sandy Bridge” processors, and later by the 22nm “Ivy Bridge” server chips when they become available next year. The system also eventually will leverage accelerator technology, such as Intel’s Xeon Phi coprocessors and Nvidia’s Tesla graphics accelerator technology, according to Bolding. Cray opted for Intel’s chips for the XC30 for their performance and connectivity flexibility, he said. The performance improvements in the current Sandy Bridge and upcoming Ivy Bridge Xeons were important to Cray, as was the ability to leverage both Intel’s Xeon Phi coprocessors and Nvidia’s GPU accelerators. In addition, Intel’s incorporation of the PCIe-3 interconnect technology into the chips. A key for the supercomputer will be the addition of the Aries interconnect technology, which is optimized for HPC environments. The XC30 will offer a 20-times improvement in global bandwidth, and the because of Aries, each node in the supercomputer will be able to handle 120 million gets/puts per second, significantly faster than the 30 million to 40 million gets/puts per second for Cray’s XK systems. Each node in the XC30s will include a 48-port Aries interconnect. Development Aries had been with Cray until April, when Intel announced it was buying Cray’s networking assets for $140 million. Included in those assets were Cray’s Gemini technology and Aries. Along with Aries, Cray is introducing its Dragonfly topology, which is designed to free applications from locality constraints and create a low-latency network that includes adaptive routing capabilities. Cray also is introducing a new cooling system aimed at leveraging what Bolding called a transverse airflow to lower overall TCO for customers. Air is blown into one end of the a row of computers and out the other end, helping to eliminate the more traditional hot aisle/cold aisle setup in many data centers. The XC30—early samples of which are shipping now, with wider availability set for the first quarter of 2013—also will come with the next generation of the high-performance Cray Linux Environment, which includes enhancements in its clustering capabilities, and Cray’s HPC optimized programming environment, which includes compilers, job management, libraries and debugging tools. According to company officials, Cray already has more than $100 million in contracts for the XC30, which has been in development for more than five years.

Message.Title: Apple not likely to ditch Intel chips for Macs in near future
Message.Msg: Theres a certain sense to recent rumors that Apple may trade the Intel chips in its Macs for the companys own processors. Apple is, after all, the poster child of a company that wants to control its own destiny: It makes its own hardware and software, and is a proponent of the walled garden ecosystem exemplified by its iTunes Store and App Store. Even more recently, Apple has taken deeper control of its processor design; the iPhone 5s A6 chip uses Apples own custom ARM-based design, rather than taking a standard ARM core and just dropping it in, as the company has with past iOS devices. However, its one thing to design a CPU thats different but software compatible with existing designs, and another thing to drop in a completely different core. Apple has done that with the Mac twice in the past, once, when it migrated from Motorolas 68000-based chips to the PowerPC architecture it co-designed with IBM and Motorola, and again when it transitioned from PowerPC to Intel. It wasnt a painless process in either case, but in both cases Apple had a key advantage: It included emulation technology that allowed the newer CPUs to run old Mac binaries (most of them, anyway). In the latter case, especially, the Intel CPUs were considerably faster than the PowerPC processors, so running in emulation mode didnt adversely affect performance too badly. Moving from Intel to ARM is a different proposition, for two key reasons: First, current ARM performance really doesnt compare with what Intels processors offer when it comes to the kind of performance expected from MacBooks and iMacs. Secondly, the currently shipping ARM-based products are 32-bit. ARM announced the ARMv8 64-bit architecture at the ARM Tech Conference on October 30th, but products based on ARMs 64-bit core are unlikely to hit the market until sometime in 2014. Intel isnt sitting still Meanwhile, Intels not resting on its laurels. Next year, the company will ship its new Haswell CPU in mid-2013. Haswell will offer somewhat better processor performance than the Ivy Bridge CPUs used in the current MacBook and iMac lines. However, Intel expects graphics performance for the integrated Intel graphics to double compared to the existing Ivy Bridge graphics. Given that Apple thought Ivy Bridge was good enough to build its new 13-inch MacBook with Retina Display using the chips integrated graphics, having even more performance will likely be an attractive proposition for Apple going forward. Beyond Haswell, Intel will be building a new CPU, code-named Skylake, on its upcoming 14nm manufacturing process, which should substantially shrink the CPU die and reduce power consumption even more significantly. Intel is betting on its processor technology to help it reduce power consumption, and Haswell itself has major tweaks for power management; at idle, it will use less power than any recent mainstream Intel CPU. Unpredictable Apple Still, Apple is nothing if not unpredictable. If we assume for a moment that Apple is really relentless about completely controlling its hardware chain, the company has more than one way to make that happen. It could move to ARM by the time the 64-bit core hits the streets; thats certainly feasible. But if so, it probably wont happen in the next generation of MacBooks or iMacs. Apple could also design its own 64-bit ARM core for Mac. As mentioned above, the company already did something similar with the A6 used in the iPhone 5. Finally, Apple could always let the Mac product line slowly wither away. This last item seems more likely. Apple could continue with Intel as long as the Mac line is alive. Meanwhile, it could gradually scale up its iPads to be more powerful and more flexible. Once theyre powerful enough for the kind of pro graphics applications that run on desktop Macs, then the writing could be on the wall. Or, Apple could keep shipping Intel-based Macs that are on the higher end of the performance spectrum, while also building a low-cost, ARM-based laptop that relies on iCloud for most of its services and storage, much the way Google is trying to do with Chromebooks. That way, it could test the waters for ARM-based Macs, and if unsuccessful, quietly move away from them. But dont expect any of this soon. Next years iMacs and MacBooks will almost certainly sport Intel CPUs. In the end, Apple still needs to ship products that serve its users needs, so replacing all of its desktops and laptops with systems running on ARM CPUs is unlikely in the short term. Beyond that, is anyones guesswell, anyone who doesnt work at Apple, at least.

Topic.Title: INtel launches Itanium 9500 and still no one cares

Message.Msg: Intel, HP unveil new powerful chip Austin Business Journal Date: Friday, November 9, 2012, 1:59pm CST Intel Corp. and Hewlett-Packard #$%$ Thursday revealed a new chip named Itanium 9500, which offers twice the power of its predecessor while using less power. The chip requires 8 percent less power while in use and 80 percent when idle, The Wall Street Journal reports. The Itanium chip line was developed by Intel (Nasdaq: INTC) and HP (NYSE: HPQ) more than 10 years ago and competes with products from IBM Corp. (NYSE: IBM) and Oracle Corp. HP on Thursday also announced a new line of servers that use the new processors. Intel designs its chips in Austin and HP operates two data centers here.

Message.Title: Wintel or Andrel - INTC wins
Message.Msg: Lots of talk out there about how tablets are cannibalizing the PCs (laptops). That is just mainstream media #$%$. Tablets, with their touch user interface, is revolutionary. As with any new type of revolutionary device, it will sell by the boatloads. Meanwhile, the PC (laptop) has reached its innovation peak and sales are down. But does it mean that tablets are replacing PCs? h*ll no! Just ask yourself these questions: Do you still own a PC? Do you still use the PC? Of course you do!...now look into the crystal ball for what will happen in the future...Windows 8 is out with touch capabilities. INTC will be coming out with a Haswell chip that will be more powerful than the current Core i's but require wayyyy less power. What does this mean? It means that there will be PCs out there that will be thinner than the thinnest Macbook Air. On top of that, these new PCs will be convertible in design, meaning that they can be both an ultrabook and a tablet. The PC is innovating again by incorporating touch UI! The tablets and PCs are merging into one device! Sure there will be some stand alone tablets out there, but convertibles will be the wave of the future. Android currently dominates the smartphone market. INTC will soon be a big player in the smartphone space with the release of their z2580 chip and subsequent chip releases...INTC has stated that for the Atom chipset, they plan to excelerate their releases. Alot of people are right now rolling their eyes and saying it's too late for INTC in this space. That's mainstream media #$%$. Do a little research. Their 3 year old z2460 chip was faster than previous ARM chips and competitive in power comsumption. The z2580 will be more powerful than the ARM Cortex A15 and will require less power. INTC has also spent the last year perfecting the performance and interoperability of Android on x86 platform. So you can say that they have not made much headlines in this space on purpose! Come end of this year and early next year, we will see! The z2580 will come out and everything will become clear as to just how great INTC really is! They will dominate in terms of performance and power consumption. The z2580 will first be built using 32nm technology. Then in mid 2013, INTC will come out with another chip built on 22nm technology and then in 2014 another using 14nm technology. But INTC's chips are more expensive you ask? INTC's gross margins will surely suffer if they try to compete in this space you say? You forget that INTC designs and build their own chips! That they can under cut ARMs chips and still make a big profit! The smartphone and small tablet market will be dominanted by Android+Intel = Andrel.
